From: "Mark Baker" <distobj@...>
>
> I've tried explaining;
>
> - why caching works
> - how firewalls do their job
> - the "exploding number of methods" problem
> - the coordination language view
> - syntax vs. semantics
> - transport vs. transfer
>
> I can't tell you why it's not getting through.  Part of it for a lot
> of people is certainly "mob mentality"; that there's comfort in knowing
> that the person beside you believes the same thing.  There's also the
> issue that mental models are hard to change, and getting this point for
> many people requires a new one.  Combined, they're nasty.

I look at the list above and it occurs to me that an "aha" moment may not be
needed in the end.  As RPC-style infrastructures proliferate, the features
you mention (caching, firewalls, simple interface, etc) will begin to
crumble (e.g. ineffective caching, overloaded firewalls, administrating a
never-ending list of interfaces/methods, etc.) around them.  They will throw
more hardware and more complex software at the problem.  And when they
discover that this isn't solving the problem (and they *will* discover
that), they will start to look around for alternatives.  And they will see
REST.  They will see applications running in ways that their own can't.  And
they will finally begin to see the light...

What better way of showing how REST is better than RPC than to let them see
how bad RPC can get?

Then again, if people don't want to see, then they won't see.
